subject: Updating 1995-era web page construction practices (was: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Shaw Alphabet Books is now online.)
msgSnippet: ... Elsewhere on the list, a few people are wondering why the page loads oddly. While the obvious culprit is  (a horribly ambiguous statement),
messageBody:
On Dec 30, 2012, at 6:35 PM, Tim <rubik67@...> wrote:

> Hey all. I've launched the web site for my new books, www.shawalphabetbooks.com It's basically a teaser page right now, but you'll be able to get your first look at the covers for the books. As for the publication date, that will be... well, you'll just have to wait and see. :-)
>


Elsewhere on the list, a few people are wondering why the page loads oddly. While the obvious culprit is <BODY BGCOLOR=0> (a horribly ambiguous statement), there are quite a few things on the page that ought to be brought up to date. While ordinarily this sort of thing would best be handled off-list, I've seen more than a few Second Shaw fan pages that use antiquated constructions like <font> elements and other holdouts from 1995. Since we've all moved on from listening to Lou Bega's "Mambo No. 5" and wearing corduroy shorts with 12" inseams, let's redo this page using more modern idioms…

Since we'll be doing HTML5, a link to the current version of the standard is in order. Here it is:

http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/

You may also want to read http://developers.whatwg.org/ which strips out stuff that only browser makers need to worry about.

From here on down, indented bits will be markup and styling, while outdented parts will be my commentary.

OK, let's start with a DOCTYPE:

<!DOCTYPE html>

This is one of the more important things that you can put in your page; it tells browsers that you want them to try and interpret your page using modern rules (as opposed to backward-compatible-with-IE3 rules).

Now for the rest of the skeleton:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en-US">
<head>
<meta charset="UTF-8">
<title>Untitled</title>
</head>
<body>

</body>
</html>

So far, so good. Let's add in the rest:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang='en-US'>
<head>
<meta charset='UTF-8'>
<title>Untitled</title>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Coming soon…</h1>
<p>The first books to be published in the Shaw Phonetic Alphabet in the past 50 years!</p>
<div>
<img src='PoeMeetsShawA4FrontCoverSmall.png' alt='Poe Meets Shaw: The Shaw Alphabet Edition of Edgar Allan Poe'>
<img src='PoeMeetsShawCondensedFrontCoverSmall.png' alt='Poe Meets Shaw: The Condensed Shaw Alphabet Edition of Edgar Allan Poe'>
</div>
<p>Coming SOON to Lulu, Amazon, and a retailer near you!</p>
</body>
</html>

This adds the text of the page, plus the images. Additionally, the images have alt attributes; this gives a way for blind people (and Google) to figure out what's actually in the images.

At this point I should probably point out that it doesn't matter to browsers whether your elements are uppercase or lowercase (<H1> vs. <h1>). Additionally, for attributes, double quotes are common, but single quotes are just fine too (and less Shift-key intensive, besides).

In any case, you should be quoting all your attribute values unless you're prepared to memorize a list of what can and can't safely be unquoted — and I never was.

----

What we have now is a page that has all the old information on it, but is now black-on-white instead of gray-on-black. Plus, it's not centered appropriately. Let's fix that:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang='en-US'>
<head>
<meta charset='UTF-8'>
<title>Poe Meets Shaw: Coming soon!</title>
<style>
html {
color: #9f9f9f;
background: black;
text-align: center;
}

img:first-child {
margin-right: 5em;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Coming soon…</h1>
<p>The first books to be published in the Shaw Phonetic Alphabet in the past 50 years!</p>
<div>
<img src='PoeMeetsShawA4FrontCoverSmall.png'
alt='Poe Meets Shaw: The Shaw Alphabet Edition of Edgar Allan Poe'>
<img src='PoeMeetsShawCondensedFrontCoverSmall.png'
alt='Poe Meets Shaw: The Condensed Shaw Alphabet Edition of Edgar Allan Poe'>
</div>
<p>Coming SOON to Lulu, Amazon, and a retailer near you!</p>
</body>
</html>

The new thing is the <style> element inside <head>; in it is a styling language called CSS (cascading style sheets). If you'd like a general reference, head on over to <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS>.

The first rule selects all `html` elements (there should be only one!) and sets its color to a gray, its background to black, and centers all text that's inside it.

The second rule selects all <img> elements that are the first child of some container element. In our case, this'll be the first <img> element inside our lone <div> element. This <img> element then gets a fairly wide right margin of 5 ems (in CSSese: five times the height of the currently-used font).

Finally, I've added a proper title to the page in the <title> element.

I'm not sure what text editor you're using to make the page, but in any case, you should be using UTF-8 (not ANSI or ISO-8859-1 or Windows-1252). This ensures the proper ellipsis that I've used in the header shows up as intended. If you're using Notepad, there's an option to save as UTF-8 (as opposed to "Unicode" — actually UCS-2) when you first try to save the file.

https://gist.github.com/4424680 shows the markup nicely formatted; if you want a fresh, raw copy head to the "raw" link in the top right corner of the markup, and get it all from <https://gist.github.com/raw/4424680/b824fa0e0fd4c029f592e0a7fd523b983d6a291d/poe-meets-shaw.html>.

Cheers,

Nathan
